title: 172 duplicate source_ids in MASTER_DEBT.jsonl â€” deduplication needed
description: MASTER_DEBT.jsonl contains 2672 items but only 2500 unique source_ids. 172 items share source_ids with other entries, indicating duplicate imports from audit sources. Duplicates inflate severity counts and make triage unreliable.
recommendation: Run deduplication script to merge or remove duplicate source_ids, keeping the most recent or most detailed version.
evidence:
Total items: 2672, Unique source_ids: 2500, Duplicates: 172
Duplicate entries likely from overlapping audit imports or re-syncs
Status breakdown: VERIFIED: 2019, RESOLVED: 298, FALSE_POSITIVE: 272, NEW: 83
suggested_fix: Run: node scripts/debt/deduplicate.js --dry-run to preview duplicates, then node scripts/debt/deduplicate.js --apply to merge. Keep the entry with the most complete data (longest description, most fields populated).
suggestion_text: Accept at S2. Duplicates inflate severity metrics and make triage unreliable. The 40 S0 critical count may include duplicates.
counter_argument: Some source_ids may be intentionally shared (e.g., same underlying issue tracked from multiple audits). Deduplication risks losing audit provenance.

title: 144 TDMS items with empty descriptions and 1 untitled item
description: MASTER_DEBT.jsonl contains 144 items where the description field is empty string, and 1 item with title 'Untitled'. These items lack the context needed for triage and resolution. Empty descriptions make it impossible to understand the issue without reading the source audit file.
recommendation: Backfill empty descriptions from source audit files, or mark items as FALSE_POSITIVE if they lack actionable detail.
evidence:
Empty descriptions: 144 items with description == ''
Untitled: 1 item with title == 'Untitled'
Total items: 2672
suggested_fix: Run a script to identify items with empty descriptions, cross-reference with source audit files, and backfill descriptions. Items that cannot be enriched should be marked FALSE_POSITIVE with reason 'insufficient_detail'.
suggestion_text: Accept at S3. Data quality issue. Empty descriptions reduce TDMS usefulness for triage.
counter_argument: Many items have titles that are self-explanatory. Descriptions are secondary metadata. The source audit files contain full context.

title: 298 RESOLVED items missing resolved_at timestamp
description: MASTER_DEBT.jsonl has 298 items with status RESOLVED but none have a resolved_at timestamp field populated. This makes it impossible to track resolution velocity or calculate time-to-resolve metrics.
recommendation: Add resolved_at timestamps to RESOLVED items based on git history of when status changed, or set to current date as approximation.
evidence:
RESOLVED items: 298
Items with resolved_at field: 0
Missing data prevents resolution velocity tracking
suggested_fix: Write a script to scan git log for when each item's status changed to RESOLVED, and backfill the resolved_at field. For items where git history is unavailable, set resolved_at to the last modified date of the JSONL file.
suggestion_text: Accept at S3. Missing timestamps prevent resolution velocity metrics. Low impact but good data hygiene.
counter_argument: Resolution velocity metrics are nice-to-have. The RESOLVED status itself is sufficient for tracking progress. Backfilling timestamps with approximations adds noise.
